pages.text: Pit Bulls have three genes that affect how they look. These are the B Locus, D Locus, and W Locus. The B Locus determines whether a dog is black or red, while the D Locus can dilute black dogs to blue. The W Locus creates white fur over top of the B and D colors.

The B Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'B' and the recessive 'b'. The 'B' allele creates black fur, while the 'b' allele creates brown fur. Dogs with one copy of 'b' will carry the brown trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for brown pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'b' will always create either brown carriers or brown puppies.
pages.title: B Locus

pages.text: The D Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'D' and the recessive 'd'. The 'D' allele does not affect the coat's color, while the 'd' allele is a dilute that creates blue-gray fur if the dog has black fur.
pages.title: D Locus

pages.text: Dogs with one copy of 'd' will carry the dilution trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for diluted pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'd' will always create either dilute carriers or blue puppies.
pages.title: D Locus

pages.text: The W Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'W' and recessive 'w'. The 'W' allele creates white fur, while the 'w' allele has no affect. Dogs with two copies of 'W' will have completely white fur, while dogs with two copies of 'w' will have no white markings. Dogs with one copy of each will have white markings and show their base color.
pages.title: W Locus
